qas.question: In which year was the last electric streetcar line removed?
How many seconds did a streetcar run along Woodward Ave in 1941?
What made car travel much easier?

context: As in other major American cities in the postwar era, construction of an extensive highway and freeway system around Detroit and pent-up demand for new housing stimulated suburbanization; <a2_0>highways<a2_0/> made commuting by car easier. In <a0_0>1956<a0_0/>, Detroit's last heavily used electric streetcar line along the length of Woodward Avenue was removed and replaced with gas-powered buses. It was the last line of what had once been a 534-mile network of electric streetcars. In 1941 at peak times, a streetcar ran on Woodward Avenue every <a1_0>60<a1_0/> seconds.
